Award.AwardTitle: Broadening participation at the 10th World Soybean Research Congress to be held September 10th-15th in Savannah, Georgia
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 10th World Soybean Research Congress will be held in Savannah, GA in conjunction with the 17th Biennial Molecular and Cellular Biology of Soybean Conference from September 10th - 15th 2017. The shared conference provides unprecedented opportunity for researchers, breeders and industry to convene and share cutting edge information about basic soybean research that can be translated to practical outcomes. Early stage scientists supported by this project will be exposed to networks of international researchers, thus encouraging training and exchange of ideas across borders and disciplines.

An important goal of the conference is to share cutting-edge science from an interdisciplinary perspective. The program includes topics at the frontier of research in pest and diseases, genetics and genomics, seed composition and nutrition and biotic interactions. By supporting 25 early stage scientists, including graduate students, post-doctoral researchers and early career faculty, the conference will promote long-term training and will serve as an incubator for new ideas and collaborations.

Institution.Name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biennial Molecular and Cellular Biology of Soybean Conference is a pre-eminent conference in soybean community focused on soybean molecular and cellular biology research, which was held in Athens, Georgia from 26-29th August, 2018. The conference focuses on all advent aspects of soybean research ranging from molecular and cellular biology to breeding and genetics. Over 400 participants from over the world attended this conference. The topics included Pests and Diseases; Abiotic stress; Symbiotic and Phytobiome; Composition & nutrition; Functional genomics; Breeding & Genomics; Biotech & genome editing; Genome biology; and Integrative genomics. With NSF funding support, a total of 46 students, postdocs and early career faculty were selected as award recipients to attend this conference. These 46 award recipients consisted of 4 assistant scientists/professors, 11 postdoctoral research associates, 5 undergraduate students, and 26 graduate students from 17 institutions in the US. Each participant had an opportunity to present their research at the conference. The participants were also provided an opportunity to tour the soybean research field at University of Georgia Iron Horse Farm. The conference has enabled these early career faculty, students, postdocs to meet and network with scientists who represent a variety of disciplines and interests in soybean breeding, genetics, biotechnology, and molecular and cellular biology.

 


Last Modified: 07/10/2019
Modified by: Zenglu Li
